response.answer_text: Because Hollywood is in the business of making movies that appeal to a specific audience.  That is, the American public. And, it's only been in the last 40 years or so that the entertainment industry as a whole has decided that African Americans are a large enough demographic, meaning it began targeting that group as a way to make more money. Before the 1960's, blacks were generally not allowed into most theaters with the general population.  However, the black public did have their own movies and, in some cases, their own theaters.  Much of the white public saw blacks as inferior, so why would they watch a movie where blacks, or browns (as in the case of Egyptians), were in a major role, either as king or queen, or as part of a larger population that was not subservient to whites.  No whites would watch it, and there would likely be protests. During the 70's, that started to change.  There were Blacksploitation films and TV shows which all featured major black characters, but when targeted at a general audience, blacks were always portrayed as poor and uneducated.  It wasn't until the Cosby Show in the 80's that it all began to change, and black characters were placed in mainstream shows and movies that were targeted at audiences as a whole. People like to see stories with others just like them.  Since white culture was the dominant one for so long (and still is to some extent), movies and TV were created to appeal to that audience.  For a long time, any attempt to change that resulted in complaints and bannings.  TV shows that featured a non subservient black were often taken off the air, particularly in the south.  Movies with strong black characters would never be profitable.  It really wasn't until 1968 when Night Of The Living Dead was made that strong, black leads capable of ordering white people around became possible.  The movie stirred a lot of controversy, but was profitable, and opened the door to more opportunities. Hollywood simply makes movies to make money.  If the majority of the population won't watch, then Hollywood will simply change to whatever is most profitable.
